questions.text: Which of the following is not a goal of the National Health Mission?

options.label: D
options.text: Reduce the incidence of leprosy to half.

questions.correct_answer: D. Reduce the incidence of leprosy to half.
questions.explanation:
• Reduce Infant Mortality Rate to 25/1000 live births (Option C).
  • Reduce Maternal Mortality Rate to 1/1000 live births (Option B).
  • Reduce Total Fertility Rate to 2.1
  • Reduce annual incidence and mortality from TB by half.
  • Reduce prevalence of Leprosy to <1/10000 population and incidence to zero in all districts (Option D).
  • Annual malaria incidence to < 1/1000.
  • <1% microfilaria prevalence in all districts.
  • Eliminate kala-azar by 2015 (Option A)

questions.text: Which of the following health programmes does the logo below represent?
Under the LaQshya scheme, what is the focus area for improving infrastructure in healthcare facilities?

options.label: D
options.text: Labour rooms and maternity operation theatres

questions.correct_answer: D. Labour rooms and maternity operation theatres
questions.explanation:
Aim

Improved care in the delivery services in the labor room and ensuring the satisfaction of beneficiaries.

Incentive
  • For providing labor room care and ensuring the satisfaction of beneficiaries.
  • Provided to health care setups - CHC, Sub-district hospital and District hospital.
  • Sub centers and PHC are not a part of LAQSHYA.
  • 80% satisfied beneficiaries will be provided incentives of:
    • Rs. 6 lakhs: For Medical College hospitals
    • Rs. 3 lakhs: District hospitals
    • Rs. 2 Lakhs: First referral units

NQAS score
  • Platinum- 90%
  • Gold- 80%
  • Silver- 70%

questions.text: Which maternal health initiative is not under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare?
questions.correct_answer: A. Pradhan mantri matru vandana yojana
questions.explanation:
Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (Option A)

 
  • This program is under the Ministry of Women and Child Development.
  • Cash incentive is given only up to 1 birth.
  • Cash incentive of Rs. 6000 given in 2 installments:
    • First Installment: ₹3,000 is given after the beneficiary registers her pregnancy and meets early antenatal care conditions, such as taking iron-folic acid tablets and receiving the first tetanus toxoid injection.
    • Second Installment: ₹3,000 is provided after delivery, following birth registration and initial immunization of the newborn with vaccines such as BCG, OPV, and Hepatitis

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (Option B)
  • On the 9th of every month, free antenatal services are provided to women, particularly in the 2nd or 3rd trimester, in government and private facilities that are part of the scheme.
  • Aim - To identify high-risk pregnancies on time.
  • This program is under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
  • Red card - Women at high risk.
  • Green card - Women at no risk
  • Blue card - Woman is a case of PIH
  • Yellow card - Women with comorbidities (Diabetes, Thyroid)

Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN) Scheme (Option C)

  • This is also under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
  • Initiative: Zero preventable maternal and newborn deaths.
  • Beneficiaries:
    • Pregnant women during the antenatal period
    • Women during delivery
    • Women up to 6 months post-delivery
    • Sick neonates
  • Total number of services provided- 18

Maa Programme (Mother's Absolute Affection) (Option D)
  • Aim- To promote breastfeeding.
  • Under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
  • Functions:
    • Lactation counselling and breastfeeding initiations.
    • Stimulation and expression support through electric breast pumps
    • Collection, storage, processing and dispensing of donor human milk

6 INTERVENTIONS

6 STRATEGIES
  • Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round behaviour change communication campaign (solid body, smart mind), including ensured delayed cord clamping.
  • Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.
  • National Anaemia Mukt Bharat Unit.
  • Intra-ministerial coordination.
  • Strengthening supply chain and logistics.
  • Convergence with other ministries.
  • National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anaemia Control.
  • Anaemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal- One-stop shop for anaemia.

6 BENEFICIARIES
  • Children, 6-59 months of age (Bi-weekly Administer 1 ml of Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron and 100 mcg folic acid per dose)
  • Children, 5-9 years of age- pink tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated pink tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid)
  • Adolescent girls & boys (10-19 years of age)- blue tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated blue tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Women of reproductive age group (20-24 years of age).(Weekly, administer one sugar-coated red tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Pregnant women- Red tablets (180 tablets)Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet should be taken starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (second trimester) and continued throughout the pregnancy (for at least 180 days). Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.
  • Lactating mothers (of 0-6 months child)- Red tablets .The tablet should also be continued for 180 days post-partum. Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.

questions.text: Which international organization collaborated with the Government of India to implement IMNCI?
At what age are children screened under the RBSK program?
questions.explanation:
RBSK
  • Launched in 2013.
  • Relies on early childhood screening and interventional services.
  • Referral Unit/ Early intervention centre - District hospital

Age group
  • 0-6 years- urban or rural slums
  • 6-18 years- government school-going children

Screening

Secondary level of prevention

Screening done for 4Ds:

  • Diseases
  • Defects
  • Deficiencies
  • Developmental delays

Referral unit- District hospital

Screened by

Mobile teams and this includes:

  • Medical officers
  • Ayush officers
  • Pharmacists
  • Lab technicians

Defects at birth

Deficiencies

  • Neural tube defects
  • Down's syndrome
  • Talipes (club foot)
  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital deafness
  • Congenital heart diseases
  • Anemia
  • Vitamin A deficiency (Bitot spot)
  • Vitamin D deficiency (rickets)
  • Severe Acute malnutrition
  • Goitre

Diseases of childhood

Development delay
  • Skin conditions(scabies, fungal and eczema)
  • Otitis media
  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Reactive airway disease
  • Dental conditions
  • Convulsive disorders
  • Vision impairment
  • Hearing Impairment
  • Neuromotor impairment
  • Motor delay
  • Cognitive delay
  • Language delay
  • Behavior disorder
  • Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
  • Sickle cell anemia, beta-thalassemia, Congenital hypothyroidism

questions.text: Which of the following is a specific objective of Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK)?

options.label: B
options.text: To increase access to prenatal care for expecting mothers.

options.label: C
options.text: To improve sanitation facilities in rural healthcare centers.

questions.correct_answer: D. To prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related mortality.
questions.explanation:
Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram(NSSK)
  • A training program launched by the Indian Government to equip doctors and nurses with essential newborn care skills, specifically addressing birth asphyxia.
  • Training program for medical officers (MOs) and auxiliary nurse-midwives (ANMs) is two days long
  • The ultimate goal is to reduce newborn mortality and morbidity.

Goals/Objectives
  • Reduce Neonatal Mortality Rate: Decrease India's Neonatal Mortality Rate to single digits by 2030.
  • Improve Newborn Care Quality: Enhance the quality of newborn care.
  • Prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related Issues: Reduce morbidity and mortality linked to perinatal asphyxia.

Strategies

  • Capacity Building: Equip healthcare providers with necessary knowledge and skills.
  • Essential Newborn Care and Resuscitation Training.
  • Updated Curriculum and Training Methodology
  • Standardized Equipment and Supplies: Provide clean, functional equipment.
  • Effective Knowledge and Skill Transfer: Improve practical application of training.
  • Focus on "Golden Minute": Quick assessment and resuscitation. Promoting Clean Birth Practices: Adhere to WHO's "six cleans". Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC). Promotion: Encourage KMC for low birth weight babies.
  • Timely Immunization: Ensure vaccination before discharge.
  • Educate parents on newborn care.
  • Effective Neonatal Transport: Establish protocols for the safe transport of sick newborns.

questions.text: What is the primary objective of the India Newborn Action Plan (INAP)?

options.label: A
options.text: To achieve universal healthcare coverage by 2030.

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce neonatal mortality rate to single digits by 2030.

options.label: C
options.text: To eliminate maternal mortality completely by 2030.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase vaccination coverage for children under 5 years old.

questions.correct_answer: B. To reduce neonatal mortality rate to single digits by 2030.
questions.explanation:
The India Newborn Action Plan (INAP)

INAP, launched in June 2014, is a targeted strategy designed to reduce preventable newborn deaths and stillbirths in India. Developed in response to the global Every Newborn Action Plan (ENAP), INAP identifies evidence-based interventions to lower newborn and maternal mortality rates.

Objectives and Goals

Strategies to Achieve Goals
  • Single Digit Neonatal Mortality Rate by 2030: Achieve <10 deaths per 1,000 live births.
  • Stillbirth Rate by 2030: Target <10 stillbirths per 1,000 total births.

 
  • RMNCH+A Framework: Implement within the existing healthcare framework.
  • Six Intervention Packages: Cover all life stages of newborns.
    • Preconception and antenatal care
    • Care during labor and childbirth
    • Immediate newborn care
    • Care of the healthy newborn
    • Care of the small and sick newborn
    • Care beyond newborn survival
  • Strategic Intervention Packages: Categorize interventions as essential, situational, and advanced.
  • State-Specific Action Plans: Encourage tailored plans based on intervention packages.
  • High Intervention Coverage: To prevent a significant proportion of newborn deaths, stillbirths, and maternal deaths by 2025.
  • Monitoring and Evaluation: Systematic tracking and dashboard indicators for progress.
  • Comprehensive Assessment: Conduct a thorough evaluation in 2020 to inform future strategies.
  • Periodic Reviews: Review milestones every five years aligned with ENAP timelines.

questions.text: What is the primary focus area of the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram?

options.label: A
options.text: Reproductive and sexual health education only.

options.label: B
options.text: Comprehensive health care along with reproductive and sexual health.

options.label: C
options.text: Exclusive focus on non-communicable disease prevention.

options.label: D
options.text: Augmentation of facility-based services for maternal health.

questions.correct_answer: B. Comprehensive health care along with reproductive and sexual health.
questions.explanation:
Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram
  • India's first comprehensive adolescent health program
  • Launched in January 2014, this initiative targets 253 million adolescents across India in their own environments.
  • It introduces peer-led interventions within communities, complemented by improved facility-based services.
  • The initiative expands the scope of adolescent health beyond reproductive and sexual health.

Target Group

Adolescents 10-19 years of age in Urban and rural areas

Focus

Girls and Boys; Married and Unmarried; In School and Out of school

7 Critical Components (7Cs)

  • Coverage
  • Content
  • Communities
  • Clinics
  • Counseling
  • Communication

6 Strategic Priorities

  • Nutrition
  • Sexual and reproductive health (SRH)
  • Non-communicable diseases (NCDs)
  • Substance misuse
  • Injuries and violence(+ gender-based violence)
  • Mental health-Peer Education Programme plays a key role in addressing adolescent health issues through trained Peer Educators, called "Saathiyas.

questions.text: Which of the following is the comprehensive program the Ministry of Women and Child Development launched to combat trafficking?
questions.explanation:
The Ujjawala scheme

The Ujjawala scheme, launched in India on December 4, 2007, by the Ministry of Women and Child Development, is a comprehensive program to combat trafficking. The scheme is primarily implemented through NGOs.

Objectives/Goals

Strategies to Achieve Goals

Prevention

  • Formation of community vigilance and adolescent groups, awareness creation
  • preparation of IEC (Information, Education, Communication) material, organization of workshops.

Rescue
  • Safe withdrawal of victims from the place of exploitation.

Rehabilitation
  • Providing safe shelter, basic amenities, medical care, legal aid, vocational training, and employment opportunities to victims.

Reintegration
  • Supporting victims in their reintegration into society.

Repatriation

  • Providing support to cross-border victims for their safe return to their home countries.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a key activity under the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme?

options.label: A
options.text: Community-based health education and outreach to promote menstrual health.

options.label: B
options.text: Providing free school uniforms to adolescent girls.

options.label: C
options.text: Ensuring regular availability of sanitary napkins to adolescents.

options.label: D
options.text: Training of ASHA and nodal teachers in menstrual health.

questions.correct_answer: B. Providing free school uniforms to adolescent girls.
questions.explanation:
Objective:
  • Promotion of menstrual hygiene among adolescent girls aged 10-19 years in rural areas.

Aims:
  • To ensure girls have adequate knowledge and information about menstrual hygiene.
  • Provide access to high-quality sanitary napkins and safe disposal mechanisms.

Key Activities:

  • Community-Based Health Education and Outreach for Promoting menstrual health in the target population (Option A).
  • Availability of Sanitary Napkins regularly to adolescents (Option C).
  • Sourcing and Procuring sanitary napkins.
  • Storage and Distribution of sanitary napkins to adolescent girls.
  • Train ASHA and nodal teachers in menstrual health (Option D).
  • Implement safe disposal mechanisms for sanitary napkins.
